title: 109_s2670
content: The Energy Fairness for America Act, also known as the "Energy Fairness for America Act," amends the 1986 Internal Revenue Code. The Energy Fairness for America Act, also known as the "Energy Fairness for America Act," amends the 1986 Internal Revenue Code by terminating various tax provisions related to oil and gas industries, including deductions for intangible drilling and development costs, percentage depletion allowance, enhanced oil recovery credit, and certain provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends the Internal Revenue Code by terminating deductions for intangible drilling and development costs, percentage depletion allowance, and the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 terminates the enhanced oil recovery credit for taxable years after the enactment date. SEC. 5 terminates certain provisions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 provisions related to oil and gas royalties, production incentives, and royalty relief are repealed. Additionally, the Alaska Offshore Royalty Suspension is terminated. The amendment related to Alaska in the Energy Policy Act of 2005 shall take effect upon enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF CERTAIN TAX PROVISIONS OF THE ENERGY POLICY ACT OF 2005. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends various sections related to electric transmission property, equipment used in refining liquid fuels, natural gas distribution lines, natural gas gathering lines, and the small refiner exception to oil depletion deduction. The Energy Fairness for America Act amends Section 1328(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 and Section 167(h) regarding geological and geophysical expenditures. The amendments will take effect on the date of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. SEC. 7. REVALUATION OF LIFO INVENTORIES OF LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The taxpayer, if an applicable integrated oil company for its last taxable year ending in 2005, must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories of oil, gas, or petroleum products by a set amount and decrease the cost of goods sold accordingly. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, the gross income will be adjusted. The "layer adjustment amount" is calculated based on the number of barrels of crude oil. The section discusses the revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies. It requires an adjustment based on the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the layer, without being considered a change in accounting method. Additionally, it specifies that no tax addition shall be made for underpayments related to this adjustment. An applicable integrated oil company, as defined in the Internal Revenue Code, must have a daily worldwide crude oil production of 500,000 barrels and gross receipts exceeding $1 billion in the last taxable year ending in 2005. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity, and the rule for short taxable years applies. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. In General, Section 901 is amended to include special rules for dual capacity taxpayers regarding taxes paid to foreign countries or possessions of the United States. Amounts exceeding the generally applicable income tax are not considered taxes. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. The generally applicable income tax is the tax imposed by the country or possession on such taxpayers. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country on income from business activities within that country. Exceptions include taxes that do not apply to dual capacity taxpayers or citizens/residents of that country. These amendments apply to taxes paid in taxable years after the enactment date, with treaty obligations being upheld. The section's provisions do not apply if they conflict with any U.S. treaty obligations. SEC. 9. RULES RELATING TO FOREIGN OIL AND GAS INCOME. SEC. 9. RULES RELATING TO FOREIGN OIL AND GAS INCOME. (a) Separate Basket for Foreign Tax Credit.--Paragraph (1) of section 904(d) is amended to include foreign oil and gas income for years before 2007 and after 2006. (b) Definition.--Paragraph (2) of section 904(d) is amended to redefine certain categories of income. Section 904(d) is amended to include foreign oil and gas income for years before and after 2007. The definition of foreign oil and gas income is clarified in the section, specifying that it does not fall under passive or general category income. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in the tax code. Section 907 of the tax code is amended, with certain sections being repealed. The effective dates for these amendments vary, with transitional rules for taxes paid or accrued before the enactment of the Act. The amendment allows for the carryover of unused oil and gas extraction taxes to the taxpayer's first taxable year after the enactment of the Act. Losses from foreign oil and gas extraction before the Act are not affected by the amendment. Elimination of deferral for foreign oil and gas extraction income. The text discusses the definition of foreign oil and gas income and makes amendments to various sections to replace "base company oil related income" with "oil and gas income." The text amends section 954 by replacing "Foreign Base Company Oil Related Income" with "Foreign Oil and Gas Income" and specifies the effective date for these amendments.
